prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO disk inclination - DK, DI, GK
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolve CO disks in binary systems to measure mutual orientation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: From our Cycle 0 observations of DK Tau and GK Tau, the peak flux in a 0.5 km/sec channel is ~0.4 Jy in a 0.5x0.7 arcsec beam. We assume that GI Tau has a similar CO flux given its strong continuum emission, which is 3 times higher than GK Tau. To achieve an SNR of 10 for these proposed observations, we need to account for the different beam size, which is a scaling factor of 3. We will smooth 4 channels together in the final analysis (see correlator section) providing a factor of 2 in sensitivity. Thus, the desired rms on these 3 sources is 0.4 Jy/10/3*2 = 26 mJy.

Our Cycle 0 observations also revealed absorption features from gas in the surrounding cloud even in 12CO(3-2), so we request a smaller channel resolution of 0.1 km/sec so that we can reject the channels with cloud absorption and then smooth to 0.5 km/sec. Both 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) are included in the correlator setup. While the 13CO may be fainter, it will also be less sensitive to cloud absorption. Though some cloud contamination may well be present, our Cycle 0 data on HK Tau showed that we can robustly recover the disk orientation even after excluding the contaminated channels.
The spectral lines for each source are only a few km/sec wide and the spread in radial velocities is several km/sec, so we only need half of the correlator channels for each line baseband (which still gives 100 km/sec of total bandwidth). The other two correlator basebands are configured for continuum.

The goal of these observations is to spatially and spectrally resolve the CO rotation in the circumstellar disks to measure the disk inclinations. From our Cycle 0 observations of HK Tau, a peak SNR of ~10 in a 0.5 km/sec channel is adequate for the modeling, but higher angular resolution provides better constraints, particularly for the inclination angle. Therefore, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec, which will provide several resolution elements across the CO disk.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO disk inclination - IT Tau
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolve CO disks in binary systems to measure mutual orientation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: From our Cycle 0 observations of IT Tau, the peak flux for the primary in a 0.5 km/sec channel is ~0.12 Jy in a 0.5x0.7 arcsec beam. To achieve an SNR of 10 for these proposed observations, we need to account for the different beam size, which is a scaling factor of 3. We will smooth 4 channels together in the final analysis (see correlator section) providing a factor of 2 in sensitivity. Thus, the desired rms is 0.12 Jy/10/3*2 = 8 mJy.

Our Cycle 0 observations also revealed absorption features from gas in the surrounding cloud even in 12CO(3-2), so we request a smaller channel resolution of 0.1 km/sec so that we can reject the channels with cloud absorption and then smooth to 0.5 km/sec. Both 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) are included in the correlator setup. While the 13CO may be fainter, it will also be less sensitive to cloud absorption. Though some cloud contamination may well be present, our Cycle 0 data on HK Tau showed that we can robustly recover the disk orientation even after excluding the contaminated channels.
The spectral lines for each source are only a few km/sec wide and the spread in radial velocities is several km/sec, so we only need half of the correlator channels for each line baseband (which still gives 100 km/sec of total bandwidth). The other two correlator basebands are configured for continuum.

The goal of these observations is to spatially and spectrally resolve the CO rotation in the circumstellar disks to measure the disk inclinations. From our Cycle 0 observations of HK Tau, a peak SNR of ~10 in a 0.5 km/sec channel is adequate for the modeling, but higher angular resolution provides better constraints, particularly for the inclination angle. Therefore, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec, which will provide several resolution elements across the CO disk.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO disk inclination - Lupus
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolve CO disks in binary systems to measure mutual orientation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The continuum flux for Sz 65 and Sz 81 is higher than for GK Tau, and we assume that CO peak flux will be similar (0.4 Jy in 0.5 km/sec channel in 0.5 x 0.7 arcs beam). To achieve an SNR of 10 for these proposed observations, we need to account for the different beam size, which is a scaling factor of 3. We will smooth 4 channels together in the final analysis (see correlator section) providing a factor of 2 in sensitivity. Thus, the desired rms on these 3 sources is 0.4 Jy/10/3*2 = 26 mJy. HO Lup has not been detected in the millimeter continuum (though there is a previous single-dish CO detection). It is added here as additional source at the same rms level and adds only 5 minutes to the total integration time of the project. The continuum sensitivity for this integration time is 0.14 mJy, over a factor of 200 better than the previous best limits for HO Lup.

Our Cycle 0 observations also revealed absorption features from gas in the surrounding cloud even in 12CO(3-2), so we request a smaller channel resolution of 0.1 km/sec so that we can reject the channels with cloud absorption and then smooth to 0.5 km/sec. Both 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) are included in the correlator setup. While the 13CO may be fainter, it will also be less sensitive to cloud absorption. Though some cloud contamination may well be present, our Cycle 0 data on HK Tau showed that we can robustly recover the disk orientation even after excluding the contaminated channels.
The spectral lines for each source are only a few km/sec wide and the spread in radial velocities is several km/sec, so we only need half of the correlator channels for each line baseband (which still gives 100 km/sec of total bandwidth). The other two correlator basebands are configured for continuum.

The goal of these observations is to spatially and spectrally resolve the CO rotation in the circumstellar disks to measure the disk inclinations. From our Cycle 0 observations of HK Tau, a peak SNR of ~10 in a 0.5 km/sec channel is adequate for the modeling, but higher angular resolution provides better constraints, particularly for the inclination angle. Therefore, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec, which will provide several resolution elements across the CO disk.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO disk inclination - Ophiuchus
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolve CO disks in binary systems to measure mutual orientation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The continuum flux for DoAr 24E is higher than for GK Tau, and we assume that CO peak flux will be similar (0.4 Jy in 0.5 km/sec channel in 0.5 x 0.7 arcs beam). To achieve an SNR of 10 for these proposed observations, we need to account for the different beam size, which is a scaling factor of 3. We will smooth 4 channels together in the final analysis (see correlator section) providing a factor of 2 in sensitivity. Thus, the desired rms on these 3 sources is 0.4 Jy/10/3*2 = 26 mJy. WSB 4, 18, 26, 28, 35, and 71 have not been detected in the millimeter. They are added here as additional sources at the same rms level and add only 5 minutes each to the total integration time of the project. The continuum sensitivity for this integration time is 0.14 mJy, over a factor of 75 better than the previous best limits for these sources.

Our Cycle 0 observations also revealed absorption features from gas in the surrounding cloud even in 12CO(3-2), so we request a smaller channel resolution of 0.1 km/sec so that we can reject the channels with cloud absorption and then smooth to 0.5 km/sec. Both 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) are included in the correlator setup. While the 13CO may be fainter, it will also be less sensitive to cloud absorption. Though some cloud contamination may well be present, our Cycle 0 data on HK Tau showed that we can robustly recover the disk orientation even after excluding the contaminated channels.
The spectral lines for each source are only a few km/sec wide and the spread in radial velocities is several km/sec, so we only need half of the correlator channels for each line baseband (which still gives 100 km/sec of total bandwidth). The other two correlator basebands are configured for continuum.

The goal of these observations is to spatially and spectrally resolve the CO rotation in the circumstellar disks to measure the disk inclinations. From our Cycle 0 observations of HK Tau, a peak SNR of ~10 in a 0.5 km/sec channel is adequate for the modeling, but higher angular resolution provides better constraints, particularly for the inclination angle. Therefore, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec, which will provide several resolution elements across the CO disk.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations of protoplanetary disks in 14 young binary systems, to test whether or not the two disks in a binary system are aligned with each other, and with the binary orbit. ALMA is currently the only way we can measure the three-dimensional orientation of the eventual orbits of planets in these systems; once the disks dissipate and the planets form, their orbits become invisible. The degree of misalignment between binary and planetary orbits has implications for planet migration and orbital evolution as well as for binary formation. In the process of making these measurements, we will test the validity of a previously-used method of measuring disk alignment, which recent ALMA observations have called into question.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Swarthmore College

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
